message.title: (!) Elections (!)
message.subtitle: Ascending Cursus Honorum
message.text: @G[c3 stills_125.png]@L @H Message @L Governor, it is time for new elections in Rome. This is a great opportunity for you to gain additional personal funds to offset any potential favor repercussions for trading with the Greeks. To be victorious in the elections, you will need to organize games to cultivate support in Rome. @L@L @G[decorative objetive .png] @H New Side Objective @L Import and stockpile 24 units of @wine and store 64 units of @wheat to send to Rome; this will be done automatically once the goods are accumulated. Rewards will be an extra 25 denarii monthly @salary which will be added automatically on top of your rank. @G[Elections.png] @G[decorative objetive .png] @L@L@L @H Historical Background @L Cursus Honorum or Course of Honors, is Roman system of political offices. Only people elected to one of the offices would hold a seat in the senate and, if elected to an office of praetor or consul, could be assigned tasks of governing provinces, administrating the Roman state and commanding legions. People who held an office in the past would have "pro" added before their title. As an example, a consul whose term has run out would be called a proconsul, allowing them to still participate in public life in the Senate and continue to serve in the provinces. Lower ranks such as quaestors would hold judiciary powers while aediles would be responsible for organizing festivities, upkeeping temples, and other aspects of public life and day-to-day operations of the Roman state. @L@L One cannot say that the system was meritocratic, since even after the rise of the Republic, patricians still held vast majority of offices and actual power. In elections the poorest citizens would only get to vote if the upper and middle strata's vote did not result in a landslide victory, in which further voting was not held by the lower classes. @L@L Before elections, it was common to organize festivities and games from personal funds to gather support from the people as well as make political alliances with other politicians. Running on a joint ticket was allowed and bribery was illegal but very common. @L@L At the top of Cursus Honorum were two consuls, the highest elected officials who held power jointly for a period of one year. Each month consuls would switch initiative in introducing legislature which Romans refer to as holding "fasces". Fasces were bundles of sticks tied together and were a symbol of ultimate state and military power. Axes would be added if a consul was on a campaign in which case he held power over life and death of any citizen. @L@L Fasces were carried by "lictors" who served as consular guard in the city of Rome and on campaign. In the city of Rome itself, there was a rule that prohibited citizens from carrying weapons, although clubs and knives were allowed. Military commanders had to resign from their command and were prohibited from bringing soldiers close to Rome unless they received special dispensation from the Roman Senate to allow a triumph. Gladiators would have an exception which some politicians used to create mercenary companies under their command. @L@L The Roman custom of demilitarizing the capital city was based on a concept of "pomerium", an imaginative border of the city. Each city usually had a pomerium, but not every city prohibited carrying of weapons. Rome's pomerium was the most sacred since Romans believed it to go back all the way to times of Romulus and Remus at the mythical founding of the city, where Romulus and his group dug a defensive trench around the Capitoline Hill which would become the original pomerium. @L@L As a justification for the fratricide Romans believed that the reason for violence was the "breach" of pomerium by Remus and thus justified his death. @L@L Size of the pomerium was eventually entirely incapsulated by outlying urban sprawl, but the pomerium would still be demarked as a trench with gates. Even so, Romans took pomerium very seriously and kept the concept sacred even at the times of festivities, when for example Pompey Magnus with a chariot pulled by elephants could not fit through one of the gates during his triumph, no one suggested going around the gate and instead a new chariot was fetched. @L@L In order for lower strata in Roman society to have a say in the matters of politics, offices of Tribunes of the Plebs were established. Tribunes would be elected solely out of the plebeian classes. Same as other elected officials, tribunes had a power of veto which could dismiss any legislation which was being proposed. This resulted in political crises in the times of Julius Caesar, where opposing parties would sandbag and veto any legislation for ideological reasons, paralyzing the whole Roman political system. @L@L@L
